Award.AwardTitle: Removing Barriers to Success in Mathematics: An Integrative Expectancy-Value Intervention

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The EHR Core Research (ECR) program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. This study extends prior theoretical and empirical work on STEM learning and STEM learning environments into community college classrooms in developmental mathematics. Developmental math courses are a major academic gatekeeper for adequately preparing students for the work force, yet many students in community colleges fail to reach college-ready math proficiency even with remediation through developmental curricula. To address this need, this study will examine the impact of a brief but promising psychological intervention designed to enhance student motivation and course learning outcomes in developmental math. The investigators hypothesize that this intervention will lead to increased perceptions of interest and performance in mathematics, which in turn will, in the short term, result in improved performance (increased course pass rates) and persistence (decreased dropout rates) of students enrolled in the community college developmental math courses that are the focus of this study. Ultimately, the investigators anticipate the foundational evidence generated by this study will provide practitioners with the information necessary to optimize interventions based on individual differences and contextual factors (practical import), and have the potential to contribute to the development of theories about for whom and why interventions work (theoretical important).

Specifically, this study is designed to provide evidence of the efficacy and effectiveness of an expectancy value intervention, combining growth mindset and utility value components. Researchers at the University of Virginia and Valencia Community College (located in Orange and Osceola Counties, Florida) will collaborate on a series of trials of one of three treatment conditions (growth mindset only, utility value only, combined growth mindset and utility value) and a 'business as usual' control condition. Intervention trials will be contained within a semester, with follow-ups coming from administrative data sets. At the end of the three-year intervention cycle nine separate cohorts of students (n=5,600) will have participated in the study, nested within class sections (n=280), nested within teachers (n=40) at Valencia Community College. Of particular interest are the individual- and contextual- (classroom and teacher) level factors which might moderate or mediate the effects of the expectancy-value intervention. Accordingly, study participants will be randomly assigned to treatment conditions at the classroom level, enabling the investigators to explore whether the intervention is more effective in some classrooms and/or with some teachers than others. Primary data to explore mediating and moderating factors will be collected via administration of a self-report student motivation questionnaire, a teacher questionnaire, and to-be-developed instruments to survey students' perceptions of the classroom learning context and teachers' beliefs about learning and teaching practices in mathematics. Student demographic and performance data will be obtained from administrative records; additionally, instructors will be asked to provide classroom-level student performance data. Complementary qualitative data will be collected from students and teachers via separate student and teacher focus groups, individual student interviews, and think-aloud protocols elaborating on the student motivation questionnaire. Analyses of these data may have potentially important implications regarding the benefits of explicit consideration of contexts when developing theories of psychological interventions in education. Additionally, the study is designed to enable investigators to replicate the intervention across multiple cohorts (testing for consistency), and to follow students longitudinally (exploring potential intervention effects on more distal outcomes, e.g., persistence towards degree completion). The investigators hypothesize the expectancy-value intervention will be both resource-efficient and practically useful - capable of being delivered to students as online learning modules amenable to widespread dissemination across large sets of classrooms and institutions. Following completion of the study, (de-identified) study data will be made available to other researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Alongside prior educational experiences and structural features of the learning context, students? motivation contributes to persistence (Bettinger, 2010; NASM Report, 2017). However, motivation declines acutely in most STEM fields (COSEPUP, 2007; NRC, 2011), with half of STEM majors leaving their field before graduation (HERI, 2010; NCES, 2011). In community colleges, as many as 54% of students fail to reach college math proficiency (Bailey et al., 2010), a majority of whom are from groups traditionally underrepresented in higher education. Motivation loss in developmental math courses is particularly concerning as these are gatekeepers to STEM majors and the workforce (Robinson et al., 2018). 

A growing body of research suggests that motivation can be altered through psychological interventions (Lazowski & Hulleman, 2016; Rosenzweig & Wigfield, 2016). Targeting students? utility value, or perceived importance and relevance of math, alongside their growth mindset, the belief that intelligence and skills can be developed through taking on challenges and using a variety of strategies, is one means to support achievement and pass rates in developmental math courses. Utility-value interventions encourage students to identify course value through reflecting on how math content is useful to their everyday lives or future goals. Growth mindset interventions teach students about neuroplasticity and how we develop skills through learning from challenges or failures. Results from numerous studies suggest that both interventions improve motivation and academic performance, particularly for students most at-risk for dropping out of math-dependent fields, such as first-generation and underrepresented minority students (e.g., Hulleman & Harackiewicz, 2009; Yeager et al., 2019).

Research Design. Over eight semesters, we collected data on 13,031 students across 434 developmental math courses and 67 instructors at Valencia College. Students were randomly assigned to receive either a growth mindset intervention, a utility value intervention, or control. Students completed two sets of activities during the semester, during week 3 and week 5 of the semester. We based intervention materials on prior studies (e.g., Kosovich et al., 2019; Rosenzweig et al., 2019), but customized them for this context (Silverman et al., 2019).

Utility-value Intervention Results. Initial analyses (N = 2,669) indicate that students in the utility-value intervention were 16% less likely to withdraw from the course compared to students in the control condition when controlling for relevant variables (e.g., student demographics, prior achievement). The utility-value intervention was also more effective for first-generation students, who received higher course grades and were 32% more likely to pass their course than those in the control condition (See Figures 1-3). Furthermore, students? responses to the utility value prompt (i.e., making specific connections between current math coursework and their lives) and their self-reported course relevance explained the effect of the intervention on course grades and pass rates (see Figure 4). 

Growth Mindset Intervention Findings. Our initial analyses (N = 1,149) revealed that the growth mindset intervention is most effective for students who not only write about the importance of believing in a malleable theory of intelligence, but also about the study strategies necessary to improve their intelligence (See  Figure 5; Wormington et al., under review).

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts. Because utility-value and growth mindset interventions require few resources and produce promising results, some researchers advocate for scaling up interventions across K-12 and higher education settings (Paunesku et al., 2015). Before scaling, we need more evidence on whether these interventions function similarly across postsecondary contexts. Because most studies have been conducted in elite four-year institutions, it is unclear whether these interventions will benefit the same students (e.g., first-generation students) or through the same psychological mechanisms (e.g., increased relevance) in other types of postsecondary contexts (e.g., community college). 

Our findings support our underlying theoretical models of intervention effectiveness. We confirmed that the utility-value intervention will work best for students who make specific connections between the math they are currently learning and their lives, rather than general connections or connections about a different type of math. We also confirmed that growth mindset intervention will only work for students who embrace both the belief that intelligence is malleable and engage in behaviors that will help them learn (i.e., approach challenge, engage in help-seeking). This is the first work, to our knowledge, that unpacks the processes that lead to the positive effects of growth mindset interventions. The coding scheme we developed is a novel methodology that other researchers could use to analyze growth mindset interventions. 

Our results also showcases how certain changes in the learning context can support students? motivation and contribute to persistence and success in developmental math. By merging data from multiple sources (i.e., administrative, gradebooks, student surveys), we can evaluate differences in motivation and outcomes based on the type of course and student characteristics. This could enable educators to better understand roadblocks for their students, and instigate ideas for potential interventions.
